awd_titl_txt: SRS RN: Convergent Innovations in Regional CirCULAR Economies (CIRCULAR)
awd_abstract_narration:
A research network organized around the goal of creating and implementing circular economy solutions could address growing social, economic, and environmental impacts facing regional systems. Using a case study based upon the city of Chicago and its surrounding urban-rural linkages, research network planning will explore the underlying system structures and interactions that give rise to unsustainable resource consumption and waste generation.  The planning will also identify potential solutions grounded in the emerging field of circular economy. The planning team will engage interdisciplinary researchers and non-academic partners in a process to co-create a research agenda for transforming regional systems towards circular economy.  The group also will explore convergent research mechanisms for the deep integration of knowledge, methods, tools, and expertise from diverse perspectives that can advance the study of regional circular economies. Finally, the team will devise a collaborative platform on which the scientific community and key stakeholders can share knowledge, translate findings, and enhance diversity and engagement.

A planning activity will be undertaken to analyze how different actors in a regional circular economy affect the stocks, flows, depletion and regeneration of various types of capital, and how explicit identification of these flows might shape potential innovations. New thinking, technologies, and business models will be explored to tackle the circular economy challenge from the front end of the supply chain by re-designing products and developing resource sharing models and from the back end by closing material loops. The creation of circular economy business opportunities, especially in marginalized urban and rural communities, will be addressed through convergent approaches encompassing multi-capital flows, data science, and public policies with participatory co-design methods. This approach elevates the knowledge and experiences of diverse participants to that of subject matter experts so that any innovations developed will result in resource conservation and will meet community needs. The team's community partners are leaders in developing and implementing new models that seek to broaden the influence of circular economy-based solutions. Throughout the efforts of this planning activity, the importance of justice, equity, diversity and inclusion to the project's framing of circular economy will be emphasized.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Modern economies operate on the premise of extracting resources from the natural environment, transforming them into products, using or consuming them, and then discarding them as waste. This “take-make-use-waste” thinking is at the core of the so-called “linear economy” and has led to rapid, although often uneven, economic growth across regions. But linear economies are also reliant on social and spatial processes that create environmental damage, including resource scarcity, mounting waste generation, pollutant emissions, and a host of impacts including global climate change. The circular economy (CE) is a promising idea that appeals to many as an alternative to linearity that aims to maximize, restore, and regenerate value while minimizing the negative impacts of waste. Our goal is to develop a comprehensive understanding of regional circularity, including its benefits, drawbacks, and opportunities and barriers to implementation.

INTELECTUAL MERIT. SRS RN CIRCULAR is composed of academic researchers, consultants, and community partners drawn from industry, government, and non-government Organizations. The study region includes metropolitan Chicago and connected rural areas. As a result of this research fifteen research projects are defined that build novel ways of integrating disciplines by focusing on shared cases, and applying different, cross-cutting transdisciplinary approaches that include economic models, materials research, data transparency and sharing, supply chain development, policy and governance models, and new innovative technologies. 

BROADER IMPACT. There are many examples of circular economies that function at the level of a single product or material, or single firm or neighborhood. Particularly relevant is the challenge of scaling to the regional level to create generalizable knowledge and broader impacts. Regional systems offer a compelling case for advancing CE research: 1) they are characterized by complex interactions across multiple scales, resource types, and system characteristics with heterogeneous waste streams that are growing in magnitude and impacts; 2) they are comprised of diverse human actors, organizations, and technologies that can be leveraged to create innovative solutions to effectively use materials and other resources, recover waste streams and retain or enhance value; and 3) they can be used to demonstrate CE solutions involving linked urban-rural areas across varied typologies, which can lead to theories of change to be generalized at a broader scale. This research has analyzed and assessed the current conditions in our study area and dominant regional regime, examined how circular innovations at small scales across the region might challenge the dominant linear approach, classified and assessed the likelihood of improved human and ecosystem outcomes under circular systems, and studied the opportunities within the regime context that would enable these innovations to take hold.
